comment._content: From en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Railways_Company "The New York Railways Company operated street railways in Manhattan, New York City, United States between 1911 and 1925. The company went into receivership in 1919 and control was passed to the New York Railways Corporation in 1925 after which all of its remaining lines were replaced with bus routes."

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Can't find anything in 1915 about "one-step" streetcars, but Public Service Regulation: Journal of the National Association of Railway Commissioners. 1(5), p 328. May, 1912 books.google.com/books?id=4cs_AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA328&l... has a piece about the safety of what is called the new "stepless" car, which has a similar picture and talks about "one step" from street to car. That article was largely taken from Brill Magazine archive.org/stream/brillmagazine61912phil#page/72/mode/2up Brill was the company that manufactured them to a design by Hedley and Doyle of the New York Railways Company.
